GSP34ghers_au:0: Introduction to transliterated text of Ghera.n.dasa.mhit-a, ed. Peter Thomi
GSP34ghers_au:1: Peter Schreiner Input conventions for the transliterated Sanskrit text of Ghera.n.da--Sa.mhit-a
GSP34ghers_au:3: The text transliterated is based on a file which represents the text as printed in:
GSP34ghers_au:4: Gherandasamhita : Sanskrit-deutsch. Ed. Peter Thomi. Wichtrach: Institut fuer Indologie, 1993
GSP34ghers_au:5: (ISBN 3 7187 0013 1). 274 pp. This file has kindly been made accessible to Peter Schreiner by Peter Thomi who has given his permission that his file be modified according to the input conventions
GSP34ghers_au:6: explained in the following paragraphs and be made freely accessible to the scholarly community. Any user of the electronic version is requested to consult the printed version for the critical apparatus,
GSP34ghers_au:7: editorial comments, translation, annotations and indexes.
GSP34ghers_au:9: Exclamation mark is used to represent the da.n.da (vertical bar, which serves as punctuation mark in
GSP34ghers_au:10: Sanskrit texts); the quarter of a verse (p-ada) is also marked by a !
GSP34ghers_au:11: (i..e. vertical bar), if a P-ada--index is to be created.
GSP34ghers_au:13: In verses of anusthubh-metre a new line begins after quarter 2 and 4.
GSP34ghers_au:14: Longer metres (longer than he /sloka, that is) are typed in such a way
GSP34ghers_au:15: that each pada gets a different
GSP34ghers_au:17: In the introduction new lines or beginnings of paragraphs are marked by dollar sign.
GSP34ghers_au:19: @ represents the asterisk in the printed edition which marks the editor's
GSP34ghers_au:20: (Peter Thomi) conjectures regarding the wording of the text. The exact place of this sign may differ slightly from where it is placed in the printed edition.
GSP34ghers_au:21: Passages which in the printed text and//or in the file appear in parentheses are put in square brackets.
GSP34ghers_au:23: The full reference (chapter and verse) is given at the end of the verse to
GSP34ghers_au:24: which it refers. The beginning of references is marked by double bar and the end is marked by a single bar. Always after a reference a new line begins.
GSP34ghers_au:25: In addition to the reference as given in the printed text, each sentence (i..e. line) is numbered in
GSP34ghers_au:26: accordance with the internal reference system of TUSTEP. This additional reference is written
GSP34ghers_au:27: between pointed parentheses; its first and second segments correspond to the textual reference
GSP34ghers_au:28: (chapter, verse); the segment after the slash counts the lines within each
GSP34ghers_au:29: verse. Lines of the base text are numbered by hundreds, with the zeros on the right margin not being
GSP34ghers_au:31: 1.2 Sandhi The "principle of transliteration" has been that the input format should reproduce the letters of the
GSP34ghers_au:32: printed text as closely as possible, i.e. that one types what one sees.
GSP34ghers_au:34: Devan-agar-i) markers are added (in the transliteration) to mark sandhi
GSP34ghers_au:36: A sandhi change is defined with regard to the "pausa form" of a word,
GSP34ghers_au:37: i..e. the form which the termination of a word would take at the end of a line or out of context (vigraha). Note that in case of nouns this pausa form is normally not identical with the declensional stem which would be entered
GSP34ghers_au:39: Thus, consonants which have undergone a sandhi change in the text are marked by *. Similarly, final vowels which have changed due to sandhi are marked by * (e..g. -as-id*
GSP34ghers_au:41: In case of vowel sandhi the above--mentioned principle of transliteration
GSP34ghers_au:42: suffers an exception: Vowel sandhi is dissolved and marked (e..g. na*asti, ca*eva). Similarly,
GSP34ghers_au:43: avagraha is reconstituted, the originally omitted initial "a" being marked as sandhi vowel (e..g. devo*
GSP34ghers_au:45: In some special cases the marking of sandhi has to be extended to include some disambiguating information:
GSP34ghers_au:46: -- to half--vowels which substitute for a long vowel the diacritic for
GSP34ghers_au:48: devy-* api); (the disambiguating sign is "added", i..e. we write "y-*"
GSP34ghers_au:49: rather than "-y*", since the minus sign is something which is not contained in the copied text but is an editorial addition by the copyist);
GSP34ghers_au:50: -- if final "a" in sandhi does not stand for "a.h" (with visarga), then the original vowel which has
GSP34ghers_au:51: been substituted by the "a" is added (e..g. lokae* eva, where "loka eva"
GSP34ghers_au:52: is printed, which is the sandhi form for "loke eva").
GSP34ghers_au:53: In case of "double sandhi" the sandhi is marked by double ** (e..g.
GSP34ghers_au:54: sa**eva in case of "saiva" instead of "sa eva").
GSP34ghers_au:55: There is one case of vowel sandhi across the pada separator (5.61/1) which is transliterated as follows:
GSP34ghers_au:57: Blank is inserted between words wherever this is possible in transliteration (but not necessarily
GSP34ghers_au:59: Separation of compounds Separation of compounds is marked by inserting + between the members of a compound (e..g.
GSP34ghers_au:60: brahma+purana). In case of sandhi, the + functions also as sandhi-marker,
GSP34ghers_au:61: i..e. no additional sandhi-marker is added (e..g. tapo+vane, mah-a+-atmana.h).
GSP34ghers_au:62: Separation of compounds is restricted to nominal compounds (including
GSP34ghers_au:64: ura+ga, go+p-i) and does not include grammatical analysis. For details,
GSP34ghers_au:65: special cases etc. see the introduction to Sanskrit Indices and Text of the Brahmapurana,
GSP34ghers_au:68: 1.4 Colophones Colophones which are part of the printed edition are enclosed by double square
GSP34ghers_au:69: 2 Textual analysis The text transliterated according to the above conventions constitutes
GSP34ghers_au:71: or "input version". On its basis two further versions are generated automatically, the so-called "text
GSP34ghers_au:73: 2.1 Text format The text format represent the conventionally transliterated text without
GSP34ghers_au:74: markers and with compounds and sandhis reconstituted. This version can be processed for output even in Devan-agar-i with programs which work on the basis of transliterated input (e..g. TeX). With metrical texts, this may serve as basis for metrical analysis.
GSP34ghers_au:75: 2.2 Pausa format The pausa format of the text is generated by changing all the characters marked by * (and + )
GSP34ghers_au:76: according to the sandhi rules of Sanskrit grammar. Each word appears in the phonetic form which it
GSP34ghers_au:77: would assume at the end of a line (e..g. aadibhir*, aadibhi.s*,
GSP34ghers_au:78: aadibhi/s*, -adhibhis* all become aadibhi.h). Members of compounds are separated. This form is the basis for
GSP34ghers_au:80: Comments and questions may be addressed to Peter Schreiner Abteilung fuer Indologie Universit aut Zuerich

GSP34ghers_au:820: <6.1/11> sthūlaṃ* jyotis* tathā sūkṣmaṃ* !dhyānasya tri+vidhaṃ* viduḥ !
GSP34ghers_au:836: <6.8/2> tad* rūpaṃ* dhyāyate nityaṃ* !sthūla+dhyānam idaṃ* viduḥ !!6.8!
GSP34ghers_au:853: <6.16/2> dhyāyet tejomayaṃ* brahma !tejo+dhyānaṃ* tad* eva hi !!6.16!
GSP34ghers_au:855: <6.17/2> dhyāyet tejo* mahad* vyāptaṃ* !tejo+dhyānaṃ* tad* eva hi !!6.17!
GSP34ghers_au:856: <6.18/1> bhruvor* madhye mana+ūrdhve ca !yat tejaḥ praṇava+ātmakam !
GSP34ghers_au:867: <6.23/2> ātmā sa+akṣād* bhaved* yasmāt !tasmād* dhyānaṃ* viśiṣyate !!6.23!
GSP34ghers_au:876: <7.2/3> dine dine yasya bhavet sa* yogī !
GSP34ghers_au:878: <7.3/1> ghaṭād* bhinnaṃ* manaḥ kṛtvā !aikyaṃ* kuryāt para+ātmani !
GSP34ghers_au:880: <7.4/1> ahaṃ* brahma na ca*anyo* 'smi !brahma*eva*ahaṃ* na śoka+bhāk !
GSP34ghers_au:888: <7.8/1> kha+madhye kuru ca*ātmānam !ātma+madhye ca khaṃ* kuru !
GSP34ghers_au:889: <7.8/2> ātmānaṃ* khamayaṃ* dṛṣṭvā !na kiṃ+cid* api bādhyate !
GSP34ghers_au:894: <7.10/2> mandaṃ* mandaṃ* recayed* vāyuṃ* !bhṛṅga+nādaṃ* tato* bhavet
GSP34ghers_au:896: <7.11/2> samādhir* jāyate tatra !ānandaḥ so* 'ham ity* ataḥ !!7.11!
GSP34ghers_au:922: <7.23/1> iti te kathitaś* caṇḍa !samādhir* dur+labhaḥ paraḥ !
